title: Why I Don't Have Fun With Claude Code
description: Stephen Brennan reflects on why using Claude Code stops being fun: he values the process of creating and understanding software, not just the end result. 'We automate tasks we don't value' - like dishwashers for clean dishes, AI coding automates something product-focused developers don't enjoy. But for Brennan, the value is in representing problems in code and building mental models of systems. He's becoming more honest about his goals: sometimes he wants to learn something, requiring the hard way. While acknowledging his job (fixing Linux bugs) requires deep expertise and debugging that AI can't replace, he's cautiously optimistic as long as his work aligns with his values of technical expertise and understanding systems.
author: Stephen Brennan

title: Are AI agents ready for the workplace? A new benchmark raises doubts
description: New research from Mercor introduces APEX-Agents benchmark testing AI models on real white-collar work tasks from consulting, investment banking, and law. Most models failed, with even the best (Gemini 3 Flash at 24%, GPT-5.2 at 23%) struggling to get more than a quarter of questions right. The biggest challenge was tracking information across multiple domains and tools like Slack and Google Drive, which is integral to real knowledge work.
author: Russell Brandom

title: Anthropic has to keep revising its technical interview test as Claude improves
description: Anthropic's performance optimization team has had to repeatedly redesign their technical take-home test for job applicants as each new Claude model improves. Claude Opus 4 outperformed most human applicants, then Opus 4.5 matched even the strongest candidates. The team had to create a novel test that stumps contemporary AI tools to distinguish top human talent from AI output. The original test was shared publicly with a challenge: 'If you can best Opus 4.5, we'd love to hear from you.'
author: Russell Brandom

title: Show HN: yolo-cage â€“ AI coding agents that can't exfiltrate secrets
description: A sandboxing tool for AI coding agents that caps the 'blast radius of a confused agent' by blocking exfiltration and regulating git access. The author created it to avoid decision fatigue from constant permission prompts when using multiple Claude Code agents in parallel. Discussion highlights: treating the agent environment as 'pre-compromised' with security-in-depth, the shift from manual coding to 'engineering' (articulating process vs translating to machine instructions), and the insight that 'tests are the core of the new agent engineering skill.' Simon Willison noted it works against accidental exfiltration but not malicious attacks (e.g., ROT-13 encoding environment variables).
author: borenstein (Hacker News)

title: Electricity use of AI coding agents
description: Analysis estimating energy use of heavy AI coding agent usage at ~$15-20/day (equivalent to 4,400 'typical queries'), comparing it to 'running the dishwasher an extra time each day' or 'keeping an extra refrigerator.' Discussion explores whether training costs should be amortized into per-token costs (they're fixed costs, not marginal), notes that Anthropic's API pricing is nearly two orders of magnitude higher than energy costs alone, and debates whether AI pricing reflects actual costs or is subsidized for growth. One commenter reports spending $1000/week on tokens and is 'happy with the exchange.'
author: Hacker News Community

title: Hacker News Discussion: COBOL devs, how are AI coding affecting your work?
description: Recent Hacker News discussion about how AI coding tools are impacting COBOL development work. Comments note that AI isn't particularly great with languages like C, Zig, or Rust either. Reflects ongoing conversations about practical applications and challenges of AI coding tools in legacy and modern language contexts.
author: Hacker News Community

title: Things I learned from burning myself out with AI coding agents
description: Discussion of an Ars Technica article about burnout from overusing AI coding agents. Key insight: 'AI coding agents' is just an autoiterating chat with a large coding model you still have to iterate over. The author spent 8 hours a day shepherding 15 Claude Code projects simultaneously. Comments explore whether this truly 'democratizes' coding (coding has been free to learn for 25 years) or just benefits those too lazy to learn. One compelling comment: people can now skip the 'coder' stage and jump straight to orchestrator (Product Owner + QA), but hit scaling traps when projects grow. The last 10% of projects requires tedious back-and-forth with the agent.
author: brazukadev (Hacker News)

title: The rise of 'micro' apps: non-developers are writing apps instead of buying them
description: A growing trend of people with no tech background building their own apps for personal use due to AI advancements. These 'micro apps', 'personal apps', or 'fleeting apps' are intended for creator-only use and temporary duration. Examples include a dining recommendation app built in 7 days using Claude and ChatGPT, a podcast translation app, a vice tracker, and a parking ticket payment automator. Tools like Claude Code, Replit, Bolt, and Lovable are enabling this shift. Mobile micro apps are emerging through startups like Anything ($11M raised) and VibeCode ($9.4M raised).
author: Dominic-Madori Davis

title: The Download: cut through AI coding hype
description: MIT Technology Review's newsletter explores the debate around AI-powered coding: whether it's giving developers unprecedented productivity boosts or churning out poorly designed code that creates long-term maintenance problems. After speaking with 30+ developers, executives, analysts, and researchers, they found the picture is not straightforward. Also covers biotech trends for 2026 and AI predictions for the coming year.
author: Edd Gent
